utterances: The things that I've done so far is do all these quizzes.
I've worn the space gloves.
It's awkward and hard.
But it's also fun 'cause at the end of one exercise where you deconstruct the plane you get some astronaut ice cream.
She'd like to make it to Mars one day.
Tonight, she says, is really helpful in getting her prepared for that.
And that's kind of the point of this sleepover.
There are volunteers like Harold Davis, who everyone calls Woody.
They're asking questions and offering tips and facts.
So what would you take to space?
Would you take borscht?
Would you take makeup?
Would you take pizza?
Sean McLaughlin, aka Alpha Whiskey Yankee, said he'd take pizza or maybe French fries.
He's actually already thought about it.
He doesn't live too far from the museum, and he comes here all the time.
But tonight is special because he can take his time reading every detail and soaking it in.
It's pretty cool when you've kind of got the place all to yourself 'cause no one else is here.
And usually when you come it's really loud and there's, like, a whole bunch of screaming.
I'm like, I can't read this.
The other magical thing about tonight?
You can fall asleep next to fighter planes from World War II.
OK, Lucas (ph), take your pajamas, please.
Thank you.
PJs.
As 11 p.m. approaches, kids - and the adults they brought with them - start to get ready for bed.
Soraya changes into her space-themed PJs printed with Saturn, the moon and the Big Dipper.
Are you going to say goodnight to all the spaceships?
I'll say, see you next time.
I hope I adventure in you one day.
Kids zip themselves in for the night, squeezing their pillows and stuffed animals just a few feet away from the right wing of the massive shuttle Discovery.
As the museum lights go dark, these spaceships dip into the dreams of these little discoverers.
Elissa Nadworny, NPR News, Chantilly, Va.
And now it's time for our staff song pick of the week.

I am not this skin.
I am not your expectations, no. I am not my hair.
I am not this skin.
I am the soul that lives within.
Again that was ""I Am Not My Hair"" by India.Arie.
Our staff song pick of the week.
Intern Kenya Young's with me now to explain herself.
Kenya, Welcome to my side of the mic.
Hey, Farai.
So what about this song resonates with you?
I really love it the song is really not about hair.
It's more about self-acceptance and really just embracing who you are with what you've got.
I think that - I know for me, personally, growing up in predominantly white areas and schools, I had a lot of cultural identity issues.
And I just think India.Arie does such a great job of saying hey, this is who we are, this who we love about - what we love about ourselves, and it's okay.
You know, not only is it okay, it's beautiful.
(Soundbite of song ""I Am Not My Hair"")

Does the way I wear my hair make me a better friend, oh?

Well, sometimes you're at a - say a public computer, or you're using some else's computer and you may want to log in and check your mail.
And you're wondering, oh, are they going to see my password, or am I going to see where I've gone to.
Maybe you're going to some websites you don't want people to know you're visiting.
Like porno.
Some people have dubbed this the porno mode.
But none of your listeners, I'm sure.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But they may have friends who want to go into porno mode and so, that's what incognito could do for them.
It'll basically let you go out and browse, and not have anything recorded at the computer at all.
When you shut that window, it's gone away and it's done.
Mm-hm.
Although, Google jokingly warns, it doesn't protect from somebody standing behind you, and looking over your shoulders seeing where you go.
Mm-hm.
Of course, Google loves to make money, and all the ads it puts up on everybody else's browser.
Are they going to be using their own browser for - as an ad campaign?
No, kind of.
(Soundbite of laughter)
They don't - I mean they don't put ads into other browsers, but of course, they have ads on a lot of the content...
Right.
Right.
You know when you go to the browsers.
So, when Google was asked that, the response was, no, we don't have all these tie-ins.
We don't have like a little special area where we're just showing ads.
And it fact the browser is very untied from Google.
You don't push buttons that automatically take you to Gmail.
It isn't going to put you into Google search by default, if you have another default search engine on your computer.
But they do say that what they hope is that more people are using Chrome, and having a better experience, then yeah, they're going to see more Google ads along the way.
